articleContent.title: Arpeggio: Dominant 7th in A#
articleContent.content:
## Arpeggio: Dominant 7th in A#

An arpeggio is the sounding of the notes of a chord in sequence, one after the other. The Dominant 7th arpeggio in A# consists of the notes A#, C##, E#, and G#.

## Notes and Intervals
- A# (Root)
- C## (Major 3rd)
- E# (Perfect 5th)
- G# (Minor 7th)

## Genre and Musical Flavor
The Dominant 7th arpeggio in A# is commonly used in jazz, blues, and funk music. It adds tension and a touch of bluesy flavor to the music. It is often played in improvisations, solos, and as a part of chord progressions to create a sense of movement and resolution.

## Songs
1. **"Blue Monk" by Thelonious Monk**
   - This jazz standard features dominant 7th arpeggios throughout the solo sections, adding a bluesy and sophisticated touch to the composition.
   
2. **"The Thrill Is Gone" by B.B. King**
   - In this iconic blues track, the Dominant 7th arpeggio in A# is used to create a soulful and melancholic atmosphere, enhancing the emotional depth of the song.
   
3. **"Pick Up the Pieces" by Average White Band**
   - This funk classic showcases the Dominant 7th arpeggio in A# in the catchy guitar riffs and solos, contributing to the groovy and energetic vibes of the track.
